page.title: Pronouns and Proper Names - Possessive Pronouns
page.introduction:
Many languages also have possessive pronouns which can stand alone, such as yours, mine, theirs, hers in English. These are distinct from those pronouns which can occur in possessor position, such as your, my, their, her, which should have already been handled in
Possessors and marked with the case of possessors.

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have stand alone possessive pronouns?
Are the stand alone possessive pronouns built by adding an affix to other pronouns?
radioGroup.radio: No, they are distinct, stand alone words
Yes, one or more affixes are used to make another pronoun possessive

form.instruction:
In the lexicon, mark each possessive pronoun with the feature possessive and also
all the relevant person (first, first_exclusive, first_inclusive, second, third),
number (singular, dual, plural), and
gender (masculine, feminine, neuter) features.
In the lexicon, add the feature possessive to the relevant affixes.
